reviewText: Three early Broadway musicals by the definitive team of Rodgers & Hammerstein are here released in a single case.  Of the three, the best is probably "Oklahoma!," filmed in 1955, which happens also to have been the team's breakout hit on stage twelve years earlier.  Gordon MacRae plays Curly McLain, a young cowboy in early 20th-century Oklahoma, who is courting Laurey Williams (Shirley Jones in her film debut), a pretty farm girl being raised by her spry and sprightly Aunt Eller (Charlotte Greenwood).  But Laurey thinks he's presumptuous and doesn't like to be gossiped about, and takes pride in the fact that she has "never...looked back to sigh/Over a romance behind me."  So she keeps running hot and cold until she finally agrees to go to the box social with her aunt's farmhand, the sinister Jud Frye (Rod Steiger), whose feelings for her are far deeper than she knew--and, as Curly finds out, frightening.  Meanwhile Curly's friend Will Parker (Gene Nelson) tries to win Ado Annie Carnes (Gloria Grahame), whose farmer father (James Whitmore) has given his word that if he's ever worth as much as $50 he can have her.  All the original songs from the Broadway version are here, and the script follows the stage book tightly."Carousel" teams MacRae and Jones again (a year later), this time in 1880's New England; he's Billy Bigelow, who barks for a travelling carousel ("Of course, it takes talent to do that well"), and she's Julie Jordan, a mill girl who falls in love with him--and he with her, despite the fact that neither of them has any intention of doing any such thing, or of marrying anyone.  But marry they do, and there their troubles begin, for they both lose their jobs over it, and Billy has no skill at anything but barking--and too much pride to try to learn any new ones.  Though a very good adaptation, this one unfortunately drops some exposition (how Julie's friend Carrie Pipperidge (Barbara Ruick) and her beau Enoch Snow (Robert Rounseville) make up, how Enoch gets so prosperous 15 years later, and how Billy ends up polishing stars in Heaven), which would have made it more enjoyable.The third movie in the set was actually the first one made: "State Fair" was filmed in 1945, a remake of a version of 12 years earlier.  Despite having introduced at least one song ("It Might As Well Be Spring") that everyone will recognize, it's much less interesting than either of the other two.  The Frake family--restless Margy (Jeanne Crain), whose longtime beau is pressuring her to marry; her brother Wayne (Dick Haymes), whose girlfriend is stuck at home owing to her grandmother's illness; mother Melissa (Fay Bainter) with pickles and mincemeat to enter in the contests; and father Abel (Charles Winninger) with his beloved prize Hampshire boar, Blue Boy--sets off for the Iowa State Fair, and there both Margy and Wayne find love (or at least they think they do) while their parents cope with the competition and the vagaries of judges.  While your mileage may vary, I found that I really couldn't get too excited about the Frakes' fortunes, and while I'll definitely be keeping the set, I doubt I'll watch this element of it another time.
summary: Three for the price of one
Title: Rodgers & Hammerstein's Triple Feature: Carousel, Oklahoma! And State Fair

reviewText: These are wonderful to watch.  I love musicals and listen to them often.  I have a collection of musicals and plan on finding more.
Title: Rodgers & Hammerstein's Triple Feature: Carousel, Oklahoma! And State Fair

reviewerName: Scott R. Lucado "I'm the other author named L...
reviewText: Some days, you just get lucky.  Not long ago, I was in a second-hand shop and found this three-disc collection for four dollars.  Yep, four bucks.  Change back from my fiver, and I took home three very enjoyable classic musicals (well, okay, two classics plus "State Fair").Alphabetically, this collection includes "Carousel," which is probably the saddest musical ever filmed, with the incomparable Gordon MacRae and the almost unbelievably adorable Shirley Jones (who is still unbelievably adorable) in a tale of tragic romance.Next, there's "Oklahoma!" which is a little dated but still has very strong performances and a lot of excellent dancing (which I feel is largely overlooked).  Rod Steiger is so smolderingly creepy (must come from living in a smokehouse) that he makes you cringe in every scene he's in.  Plus, it's a kick to see James Whitemore as Gloria Graeme's father, when he was only two years older than her.  Seeing Shirley Jones (*sigh*) in her first starring role is worth the price of admission alone.  It's hard to believe she was 20 or 21 when this was filmed; she simply radiates, and has a voice to charm the stars down from the skies.Finally, "State Fair" provides a lot of fun, with the unlikely casting of Dana Andrews in a musical.  This was of course the only musical that Rodgers & Hammerstein wrote especially for the movies, and it's not one of their best works, but it's certainly enjoyable.  If nothing else, it'll give you a good idea for spicing up a mince pie!In summary, even if you don't have the good fortune to find this collection for four dollars, it's worth whatever you have to pay.
summary: Three big-screen musicals worth every penny
Title: Rodgers & Hammerstein's Triple Feature: Carousel, Oklahoma! And State Fair

reviewText: three good movies from times gone by.  I'm tickled to have in my library.  I don't recall if I've ever seen State Fair B-4 but will eventually see it.
Title: Rodgers & Hammerstein's Triple Feature: Carousel, Oklahoma! And State Fair

reviewText: They are the movies: Carousel, Oklahoma and State Fair.If you like all 3 movies then I suggest that you buy this triple set of dvds. You won't be disappointed.Susan P. Keefe
summary: Rodgers & Hammerstein's Triple Feature: Carousel, Oklahoma! and State Fair dvds
Title: Rodgers & Hammerstein's Triple Feature: Carousel, Oklahoma! And State Fair
